entries.title: How Tokyo Series prepared Cubs' Matthew Boyd for WBC ramp-up
entries.summary: <p>MESA, Ariz. – When left-hander <b>Matthew Boyd</b> jogged out to the mound for his first spring training start, he and the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs" >Cubs</a> already had a good sense of the World Baseball Classic schedule he was building up to.</p><p>“I'm not going to be doing something, in terms of between the white lines, that's different than what I've done before,” he said after throwing 1 ⅔ innings Saturday in the Cubs’ 3-2 loss to the Rangers.</p><p>Boyd praised Team USA manager <b>Mark DeRosa</b> and pitching coach <b>Andy Pettitte </b>for their communication with Cubs manager <b>Craig Counsell </b>and pitching coach <b>Tommy Hottovy</b>. The plan, Boyd said, is to use him like a starter – but that also includes piggyback setups like the Cubs used last March in Tokyo.</p><p>For the second exhibition game in Japan last spring, Boyd technically entered in relief, but that was scripted. He went through his normal start-day routine, and the Cubs had reliever <b>Daniel Palencia</b> throw ⅔ of an inning to bridge the gap between right-handed starter <b>Jameson Taillon</b> and Boyd.</p><p>In that game, on March 16, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs/2025/03/16/cubs-matt-boyd-has-his-best-outing-so-far-this-spring-in-exhibition-game-vs-yomiuri-giants" >Boyd showcased a jump in velocity</a>. Then he went on to have a healthy 2025 season and collect the first All-Star selection of his career.</p><p>This year's WBC is in a similar time frame, running from March 6-17.</p><p>“Very comparable," Boyd said. “That's part of the reason why it was such an easy yes to go do the WBC stuff, is this because it's very similar to what we did.”</p><p>On Saturday, Boyd struck out two of the first three batters he faced but allowed three singles in the first inning. He navigated the traffic successfully to keep the Rangers from scoring.</p><p>The second inning played out similarly, with two strikeouts, a double and a single. But Boyd allowed a run before handing the ball over with two outs.</p><p>“It was good work,” Boyd said, “Pitched with some runners on base, had to work with a guy on second, had to start some guys off with off speed and whatnot.”</p><h3><b>Long exits after collision</b></h3><p>Cubs first baseman <b>Jonathon Long </b>left the game in the fourth inning Saturday with a sprained left elbow, according to the team.</p><p>As the Rangers’ Mark Canha raced up the line to beat out a ground ball to the left side of the infield, shortstop <b>Jefferson Rojas</b>’ throw pulled Long into the basepath. Canha ran into Long’s extended glove. Long dropped the ball, and hunched over, cradling his left arm.</p><p>After an on-field examination, Long exited the field with head athletic trainer <b>Nick Frangella</b>.</p><p>Long, a non-roster invitee, was scheduled to depart Cubs camp next week to join the Chinese Taipei national team for the WBC. The injury raised questions about his availability for the tournament, but he will be re-evaluated Sunday.</p><h3><b>Ballesteros en route</b></h3><p>On top of the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs/2026/02/15/cubs-moises-ballesteros-likely-to-be-delayed-by-visa-issues-for-another-week" >visa issues catcher<b> Moisés Ballesteros</b> had been navigating,</a> he also went through flight delays, manager <b>Craig Counsell </b>said Saturday. Ballesteros was not in camp Saturday morning, but he had reached Houston, Texas – a promising sign in a saga that’s already delayed his arrival a week and half past his report date.</p><p>He’s not expected to appear in spring training this week, as he ramps up, but Counsell isn’t expecting the delay to impact Ballesteros’ readiness for the season.<br></p>
entries.author: Maddie Lee

entries.title: Chicago clergy kick off funeral services with tribute to Rev. Jesse Jackson
entries.summary: <p>Deborah Cosey-Lane couldn't help but grow emotional as she listened to clergy from across Chicago honor Rev. Jesse Jackson’s life and legacy during a heartfelt tribute Saturday morning at the headquarters of the Rainbow PUSH Coalition.</p><p>“I still have life in me because I have hope,” said Cosey-Lane, 60. “That hope was instilled because the reverend kept pouring it in when I looked like I was empty and like I was hopeless.”</p><p>Cosey-Lane was one of dozens who gathered for Rainbow PUSH’s Saturday morning forum kicking off funeral services for Jackson, who <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/obituaries/2026/02/17/rev-jesse-jackson-civil-rights-leader-rainbow-push-obituary" >died peacefully Tuesday at the age of 84</a>.</p><p>Jackson founded the Rainbow PUSH Coalition in 1970.</p><p>Cosey-Lane met Jackson in 2016 after moving from St. Louis to Chicago and said he was instrumental in helping her “fight for herself.” She met the civil rights icon when she served as a leader in the Amalgamated Transit Union, and said he stood with them as they pushed for stronger contracts.</p><p>“And as a woman surrounded by men in leadership, he always encouraged me to not listen to the noise and always keep your faith,” Cosey-Lane said.</p><p>During the tribute, clergy from across the city gave tribute to Jackson by sharing stories of the reverend’s impact.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure Michael Eaddy of the People’s Church of the Harvest speaks during the Saturday Morning Forum at Rainbow PUSH Coalition in Kenwood.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Pat Nabong/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Rev. Michael Eaddy of the People’s Church of the Harvest in East Garfield Park said Jackson inspired him to take social action.</p><p>“He inspired me in my role and as a pastor not to be confined to my church building nor to my congregants only, but to make an impact on my community and people at large,” Eaddy said.</p><p>Jackson <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2026/10-facts-reverend-jesse-jackson-sr-chicago-connection" >rose to prominence</a> in the 1960s as a protege of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.. The reverend joined King’s cause and carried that mission to Chicago, where he championed key causes of the Civil Rights Movement, including racial equality, economic justice and human rights.</p><p>“He was my hero. He was my mentor,” Eaddy said.</p><p>Jackson’s wife, Jacqueline Jackson, and children sat in the front row during the forum while members of the community filled almost every seat in Rainbow PUSH’s South Side auditorium.</p><p>Rev. Ciera Bates-Chamberlain said the best way to honor Jackson was to continue to “keep hope alive,” the signature rallying cry of the late reverend.</p><p>“Dr. King gave us a dream and he spoke of a dream,” said Bates-Chamberlain, executive director of Live Free Illinois. “The Rev. Jackson spoke of hope.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item"> <bsp-carousel class="Carousel Enhancement" data-align-center> <a class="AnchorLink" Jesse Jackson’s death</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>Demetrice Pearson, 62, said she would “keep hope alive” by serving her community and teaching others about Jackson.</p><p>“He gave his life to helping people and serving people,” said Pearson, a member of Rainbow PUSH.</p><p>Services will continue as<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago/2026/02/17/what-we-know-rev-jesse-jacksons-death-services" > Jackson lies in repose</a> Thursday and Friday at Rainbow PUSH’s Kenwood headquarters at 930 E. 50th St. The services both days will start at 10 a.m.</p><p>His remains will then travel to South Carolina and Washington, D.C., from March 1 to 5.</p><p>A “People’s Celebration” in Chicago will be held at 10 a.m. March 6, at House of Hope, 752 E. 114th St. Doors open at 9 a.m.</p><p>Private homegoing services are scheduled for 10 a.m. March 7, at Rainbow PUSH. Doors open at 8 a.m., with limited capacity.</p>
entries.author: Cindy Hernandez

entries.title: Bulls and Pistons confident that Jaden Ivey can come back from injury
entries.summary: <p>In the eyes of the Pistons and head coach J.B. Bickerstaff, it was never about if Jaden Ivey would recover from the horrific leg injury he suffered last season with Detroit, but what would be the timeline?</p><p>That question is still being asked, especially in the wake of Saturday’s news that the Bulls – Ivey’s new team thanks to the trade deadline – has shut him down for at least two weeks, concerned with how he’s looked since the deal was made.</p><p>“We expected a full recovery, but the timing you never know, which is something you can never know,” Bickerstaff said. “And then the part for him is believing and trusting in it, that happens with the injury too, especially when you’re explosive and your athleticism is so unique. You got to find that trust back in it.”</p><p>Which Ivey obviously has struggled with.</p><p>In his first 30 games pre-injury last season, Bickerstaff was watching Ivey take off, filling it up with 17.6 points per game and shooting just under 41% from three.</p><p>In his return to play this season, Detroit was giving him 17 minutes per game, he was averaging 8.2 points and shooting 37% from three with obvious drops in his play-making and explosiveness. In his first four games with the Bulls, he was getting the minutes before not playing against Toronto but looked caught in cement far too often.</p><p>There was a lot of controversy coming out of his DNP (Did Not Play) and it wasn’t helped when he declared “old J.I. is dead” afterward, but Bulls coach Billy Donovan said it was decided before that Thursday game that Ivey would sit so he could get the soreness in his knee checked out a day later.</p><p>“Certainly, it was our decision coaching-staff wise that he did not play, but I think medical guys saw that he was not moving great,” Donovan said. “They had something scheduled (Friday) to get him looked at. Clearly, we’ve got to remove some soreness to get him better, but he has to do some strengthening too with a lot of the muscles around his knee.”</p><p>That will be the immediate plan for the guard. Two weeks of strengthening and getting the leg stronger and then a re-evaluation. That doesn’t mean he’ll play again this season, but that remained the hope.</p><p>“Being able to come back from that type of injury isn’t easy,” Bickerstaff added of Ivey. “Having to do it in a situation where the team has kind of established itself when you were away, and now you’re trying to find your rhythm and not step on anyone’s toes … he wasn’t in an easy situation.”</p><p><b>A big yes</b></p><p>The Bulls also announced that Zach Collins would miss the rest of the season, as doctors have decided that his toe injury would be better served if he underwent surgery.</p><p>The often-injured big man only played 10 games this season and will be a free agent, but Donovan was all in for bringing him back.</p><p>“When a guy is in free agency there’s the financial piece of it and then there’s the part of the player, the make-up, the character,” Donovan said. “It’s hard for me knowing what a guy’s value is financially, but from my perspective as it relates to winning, when he’s out there and healthy he’s a very good player for us. From that standpoint I would hope it would all work out for him to be back here next year.”</p><p><b>Happy return</b></p><p>Eastern Conference-leading Detroit got reinforcements back against the Bulls as Jalen Duren’s two-game suspension for a Feb. 9 fight with Charlotte ended. The Pistons were still without Isaiah Stewart, who was suspended seven games for his part in the altercation.</p>
entries.author: Joe Cowley

entries.title: Cubs' Matt Shaw gets first spring training start in right field: 'A lot of fun'
entries.summary: <p>MESA, Ariz. – <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs" >Cubs</a> right fielder Matt Shaw dropped-stepped to his right and then switched back to his left to camp under a fly ball.</p><p>That catch in the fourth inning was essentially the only action Shaw got in the Cubs’ 3-2 loss Saturday to the Rangers. He also picked up a ground-ball single that deflected off the end of second baseman James Triantos’ glove as he dove, and threw it in.</p><p>“Definitely a lot of fun,” Shaw said. “Listening to [center fielder Pete Crow-Armstrong,] he's guiding me along.”</p><p>Shaw’s first spring training game in the outfield wasn’t much of a test. But he’ll get more opportunities as he continues to learn the position.</p><p>“You want the tougher plays, you want the plays that don't happen as much,” manager Craig Counsell said Saturday morning. “The fly ball that goes straight up and then he catches it, and then we all [say,] ‘Oh, he can play right field,’ that tells us nothing.</p><p>“We're looking for more than that. So, you want action, you want weird plays. Those are the experiences that make you better and cause growth. And the best way to do it is just have innings out there.”</p><p>Shaw, transitioning this year from third base to a utility role, has had similar conversations with Counsell. The Cubs plan to play Shaw all over, but outfield will be a focus in spring because he’s had fewer game reps there.</p><p>“It feels like I'm kind of a kid again, running around, catching balls, diving and stuff,” Shaw said earlier this spring.</p><p>Shaw played outfield growing up, with his most recent experience coming five years ago in collegiate summer ball.</p><p>“The biggest challenge is, now that I'm going to be playing outfield, playing second, playing third, just balancing all of that,” Shaw said, “making sure I can stay healthy and stay in good shape.”</p><p>In addition to the Cubs coaching staff, left fielder Ian Happ is someone Shaw can lean on for advice as he finds that balance. Happ came up as a utility player before finding a home in the outfield.</p><p>“I'm sure he'll be <i>super</i> helpful,” Shaw said. “He already has been.”</p><p>Shaw told the story of how he reached out to Happ about whether he should get a 14 ½ -inch outfielder’s glove. The problem is, manufacturers don’t make baseball gloves that big, which Happ made sure to let him know. Anything longer than 13 inches is banned in the MLB rulebook.</p><p>“It’s the little things, you know?” Happ said.</p><p>He was joking, but the quip actually summed up Happ's real advice for juggling multiple positions. Early in his career, Happ leaned on super utility player Ben Zobrist for guidance.</p><p>“You want to go and do a bunch of things in the outfield and be the best outfitter you can be,” Happ said. “But Ben Zobrist was really good with me about, it's not necessarily about making the flashy plays, it’s about doing all the little things.”</p><p>Happ plans to have similar conversations with Shaw this spring.</p><p>Shaw can drill down on technique in practice. But there are some elements to outfield defense, like communication, situations, and navigating the wall, that can’t be fully replicated in that setting.</p><p>“True, true game speed, has to happen in-game,” Counsell said.</p><p>Once Shaw gets comfortable playing outfield in spring training, the next challenge will be playing right at Wrigley Field.</p><p>“Be careful with the wind,” right fielder Seiya Suzuki said through interpreter Edwin Stanberry when asked what his advice would be. “And be careful about the wall next to the foul line; it's dangerous.”<br></p>
entries.author: Maddie Lee

entries.title: Woman killed in Far South Side drive-by shooting
entries.summary: <p>A woman was killed and another wounded in an East Side neighborhood drive-by shooting early Saturday on the Far South Side.</p><p>Just after 1 a.m., both women, ages 29 and 37, were in a crowd gathered in a parking lot in the 10200 block of South Avenue J when someone opened fire from a passing blue vehicle, according to a statement from Chicago police.</p><p>The older woman was hit in the leg and the younger in the chest. They were taken to the University of Chicago Medical Center, where the 29-year-old woman later died, police said.</p><p>The 37-year-old woman was in good condition. No one was in custody as detectives investigated Saturday morning.</p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: 2 hospitalized in East Garfield Park apartment fire
entries.summary: <p>Two people were hospitalized after an apartment fire Saturday evening in East Garfield Park on the West Side. </p><p>The two-alarm fire broke out sometime before 6:30 p.m. in the 3400 block of West Madison Street, according to the Chicago Fire Department. </p><p>Two people were taken to area hospitals with unspecified injuries, fire officials said. </p><p>There were about 20 residents were displaced due to the fire, according to Chicago police scanner audio. </p><p>The cause of the fire wasn’t immediately known. </p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Police release photo of car sought in Englewood hit-and-run that seriously injured 2 girls
entries.summary: <p>Chicago police released a photo of a vehicle wanted in connection with an Englewood hit-and-run that injured a teenage girl and a 6-year-old child Friday morning on the South Side. </p><p>The vehicle was described as a white and black 2010 Lincoln MKT with llinois license plate number "FS73498," police said in a community alert. The vehicle may have damage to the front, hood and windshield and has a sticker on the left side of the rear window. </p><p>About 7:40 a.m. Friday, two girls, 15 and 6, were crossing the street in the 1700 block of West 69th Street when the vehicle struck them and did not stop, police said. </p><p>The 6-year-old girl was taken to Comer Children's Hospital in critical condition after sustaining several injuries. The teen sustained scrapes and was transported to Comer in serious condition, police said. No other injuries were reported.</p><p>Anyone who sees the vehicle is encouraged to call the Major Accidents Investigation Unit at (312) 745-4521 or submit a tip at <a class="Link" href="https://www.p3tips.com/TipForm.aspx?ID=727#" target="_blank" >CPDTIP.com</a> using reference #JK-156072. </p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Bears Hall of Famer Steve McMichael's widow, Misty, arrested
entries.summary: <p>Misty McMichael, who was part of the successful lobbying effort for her husband Steve’s inclusion into the Pro Football Hall of Fame before his death in April 2025, was arrested Friday and charged with domestic battery.</p><p>Will County sheriff's deputies arrested McMichael, 55, at a Frankfort home, where she was accused by an unnamed man of arguing for hours and choking him. A witness said the two had been arguing. Records indicate she was charged with misdemeanor domestic battery and physical contact. She was booked at 7:23 a.m. Friday.</p><p>Steve “Mongo” McMichael <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2025/04/23/bears-steve-mcmichael-dies-obituary-als-hall-of-fame-defensive-lineman-nfl" target="_blank" >died at 67 in April</a>, four years after being diagnosed with ALS. The defensive lineman played for the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >Bears</a> from 1981 to 1993 and ranks second in franchise history in sacks and third in tackles. </p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-740000" name="image-740000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/41432ee/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4243x2381+0+224/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F25%2F65%2Ffcdc27a04f9b819c1b55a90220e2%2Fhall-of-fame-football.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/cee34c7/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4243x2381+0+224/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F25%2F65%2Ffcdc27a04f9b819c1b55a90220e2%2Fhall-of-fame-football.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/2ad204d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4243x2381+0+224/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F25%2F65%2Ffcdc27a04f9b819c1b55a90220e2%2Fhall-of-fame-football.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Misty McMichael receives the gold jacket for her husband, Steve McMichael, a member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame Class of 2024, during the gold jacket dinner in Canton, Ohio, on Friday, Aug. 2, 2024. He received a gold jacket at his Homer Glen home, with fellow Hall of Famers Richard Dent, Jimbo Covert and Mike Singletary by his bedside.</p>
entries.author: Patrick Finley

entries.title: Black artists express complicated relationship with U.S. flag in show honoring nation's 250th anniversary
entries.summary: <p>Inspired by their lived experience and worldview, Black artists have reimagined one of the country’s most recognizable symbols in a new exhibition at Zhou B Art Center.</p><p>There are several depictions of the American flag at the “<a class="Link" href="https://www.pigmentintl.com/post/glory-glory-opens-this-friday-at-zhou-b-art-center-register-today" target="_blank" >Glory! Glory</a>!” show, which opened Friday. Some are missing stars, others hang upside down. One replaces the stars with tufts of cotton and the white stripes with African prints. Another, "American't" by Nnaemeka Ekwelum, is woven with plastic lacing material. It is also adorned with military dog tags bearing the names of Black children killed by police or otherwise harmed in the country.</p><p>“I like the idea of looking at this image and saying, ‘Something is off about this,’” said Ekwelum, 35, of Rogers Park. “And I think that's how we should feel when we look at the flag.”</p><p>The exhibition is on view at the Bridgeport venue Monday through Friday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m., through March 20. It is part of Pigment International’s year-long programming, “America 250 — We ARE the people,” which honors the 250th anniversary of the nation's founding.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-7c0000" name="module-7c0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><b>‘Glory! Glory!’</b><br><br><b>When:</b> Through March 20<br><br><b>Where:</b> Zhou B Art Center, 1029 W. 35th St.<br><br><b>Info:</b> <a class="Link" href="https://www.pigmentintl.com/" target="_blank" >pigmentintl.com</a></div> </div><p>The Black-owned arts nonprofit is centering Black artists as part of the initiative, which is happening during a time fraught with political tension. The Trump administration is encouraging artistic celebrations of America’s 250th birthday as it dismantles civil rights protections and diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives for Black Americans. “Glory! Glory!” captures that dissonance with pieces by artists who say they are telling a full and complicated story of America.</p><p>“You can't divorce us from this history,” said Patricia Andrews-Keenan, founder of Pigment International. “I’m patriotic. Sometimes that can be a little bit of a conflict because I know the good parts of our history and I know the bad parts of our history, but it's still our history.”</p><div class="Enhancement" </div><p>The Trump administration is awarding <a class="Link" href="https://www.arts.gov/initiatives/celebrating-americas-250th-anniversary" target="_blank" >National Endowment for the Arts grants</a> for anniversary-based programming, but Pigment International was not selected as a grantee. The nonprofit was able to secure state funding from Rep. Kimberly du Buclet (D-Chicago), who chairs the Museum, Arts, Culture and Entertainment committee.</p><p>A different U.S. president is the focus of the “Glory! Glory!” exhibition’s centerpiece. Titled “44,” Robert Lewis Clark’s 11-by-8-foot mixed-media work featuring an image of Barack Obama on the American flag. The piece also includes 44 colorful wooden stars and red and white stripes painted over newspapers announcing Obama’s historic win in the 2008 presidential election.</p><p>“I wanted to inspire people to achieve their goals,” said Clark, 58, who created the piece more than a decade ago, when Obama was still in office. The Hyde Park native has since donated a print to the Obama Presidential Center.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a Stacey Abrams, who worked to expand voting rights." width="375" height="500" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/c7930e3/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4412x5883+0+366/resize/375x500!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fa2%2F5e%2Ffcee23ec468294bcd9f1a47a3a0a%2Fblackflag-260222-003.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSI1MDBweCIgd2lkdGg9IjM3NXB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Paul Branton’s “Change Under Georgian Sky” is a portrait of former Georgia state Rep. Stacey Abrams, who worked to expand voting rights.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Arthur Maiorella/For the Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Another politician, Stacey Abrams, is the subject of Paul Branton’s mixed-media piece, “Change Under Georgian Sky.” The portrait of the former minority leader in the Georgia House of Representatives features stars and stripes of the American flag, along with a miniature Confederate flag.</p><p>Citing Abrams' voting rights advocacy, which helped Joe Biden win Georgia in the 2020 presidential election, Branton said Abrams reminds him of Black Americans' continuous fight for justice.</p><p>“Being Black in America is basically being in love with someone that does not love you back,” said Branton, 52, of Beverly. “It’s trying to gain the attention and the admiration of someone that sometimes flirts with you and other times is very abusive to you.”</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/arts-and-culture/2026/02/19/chicago-diversity-survey-arts-organizations-joffrey-ballet-goodman-theatre-architecture-center" >More of Chicago’s top arts organizations agree to share diversity data following WBEZ/Sun-Times survey</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>Artist Reggie McFly said he expresses that dichotomy in his piece, "In the Land of the Free." Using the flag as a backdrop, the acrylic painting reimagines "The Scourged Back," a famous Civil War-era photograph that shows the scars on the back of an enslaved man. </p><p>"I grew up listening to the national anthem and holding the flag in such high regard,” said McFly, a 37-year-old Roseland native. “But seeing the image of slavery, how could you ever disconnect the two? It was so brutal, and a lot of people lost their lives for what was supposed to be a symbol of freedom. Did that freedom ever include us?”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-580000" Black children killed by police or otherwise harmed in the country.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Arthur Maiorella/For the Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Artist Candace Hunter of Kenwood did not spend time wrestling with the answer.</p><p>"We have never really been included in the full understanding of the word 'American' by the people who own the word," she said.</p><p>Hunter said she wanted to emphasize the contributions of African Americans with her works in the exhibit. For "Heads/Hearts/Hands," she constructed a flag from mud cloth, and sashes from fashion designer Brenda Winstead, who specializes in African prints known as Damali wear. Hunter also included organza bags of cotton, which was cultivated by enslaved Africans. Her "Birth of a New Nation" piece features an American flag flowing out of a split in a hand-carved Makonde belly mask from Africa.</p><p>"This reality we're living through really goes to show that there are those who still see us as separate from them," she said, "and yet nothing they can do can be done without us and our history in this land."</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> entries.summary: <h2>Moon Alert</h2> <p>There are no restrictions to shopping or important decisions today. The moon is in Taurus.</p><h2>Aries (March 21-April 19)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-6f0000" name="html-embed-module-6f0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>dynamic</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Lucky you! This is a feel-good day and an excellent day for financial benefits. You might see ways to boost your income. You might buy something to improve your home or gift a family member. Any purchase will likely please you. Ka-ching!</p><h2>Taurus (April 20-May 20)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-6f0000" name="html-embed-module-6f0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>dynamic</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> This is a wonderful day because the moon is in your sign dancing with Venus and Jupiter, which makes you feel happy to be alive. In addition, relations with friends and members of groups are positive and upbeat. It's a fantastic day to schmooze. Enjoy yourself!</p><h2>Gemini (May 21-June 20)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> You make a fabulous impression on everyone today. Some of you might turn this advantage into a financial perk. You might get a great job offer or see how to boost your wealth in some way. You might buy something to promote your image. Looking good!</p><h2>Cancer (June 21-July 22)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-6f0000" name="html-embed-module-6f0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>dynamic</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> This is a fantastic day to schmooze! If you can travel, by all means, do so. Enjoy meeting new faces and seeing new places because you'll be thrilled to do something to expand your world. Romance is blessed! New love is possible. Kiss, kiss, hug, hug.</p><h2>Leo (July 23-Aug. 22)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> People notice you today, and they will admire you because financial negotiations favor you today. Keep your pockets open because money might come to you. People will benefit you. Don't hesitate to ask for a favor. However, be patient with partners and close friends.</p><h2>Virgo (Aug. 23-Sept. 22)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-6f0000" name="html-embed-module-6f0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>dynamic</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Romantic vibes are excellent for your sign today. You might meet someone different who is from another culture or different from your regular expectations. This is the classic day for romance to blossom. It's a productive day for you, but it's also friendly and social.</p><h2>Libra (Sept. 23-Oct. 22)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> This is an excellent day to negotiate with others or ask for help from co-workers or health care workers. People will benefit you today, and a work-related romance might begin. Even though you will accomplish a lot today, take time out for fun.</p><h2>Scorpio (Oct. 23-Nov. 21)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-6f0000" name="html-embed-module-6f0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>dynamic</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Today you are blessed with a fun-loving, playful day that is friendly, romantic and stimulating. (Do get dressed.) Get out and schmooze. Meet friends, or enjoy your own solo adventure. Give yourself a mini vacation today — a treat you deserve.</p><h2>Sagittarius (Nov. 22-Dec. 21)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Everything to do with home and family, as well as work and helping others, is beautifully favored today.
